habitat_description:
The Herring Gull (Larus argentatus), breeds in northern Alaska, across northern Canada, Hudson Bay, the Great Lakes, and along the Atlantic Coast to Hatteras, North Carolina (Pierotti and Good 1994).  It inhabits the shorelines of oceans, seas, lakes, and large rivers (Pierotti and Good 1994).

This species generally nests in colonies, often large ones.  Successful nesting appears to require sites that are near water and safe from terrestrial predators.  Islands, offshore rocks, dredge spoil islands, marshy hummocks, barrier beaches, rooftops (reported in Portland, ME and Boston, MA), and abandoned piers (Pierotti and Good 1994) can all be suitable nesting sites.  Breeding success is often highest in places with vegetation that provides cover for semiprecocial young from weather and predation (Pierotti and Good 1994).

Herring Gulls are opportunistic scavengers and predators. Their diet consists of aquatic invertebrates, fishes, birds, carrion, and human refuse. Foraging occurs on the shorelines of open waters, at sea, fields, and garbage dumps (Nature Serve 2004, Pierotti and Good 1994, and BISON-M).  Foraging areas are often separate from nesting sites (Pierotti and Good 1994).  

The Herring Gull is an uncommon to common species found throughout the Southwest Regional GAP area where it is a migratory species throughout the region and a winter resident in certain portions of the southwest (NatureServe 2004, Pierotti and Good 1994).  During migration in the Southwest Regional GAP, this species is known to occur in all five states. The Herring Gull is a winter resident in eastern Colorado, eastern and southern New Mexico, the lower Colorado River in Arizona, Lake Mead in Nevada, and the Great Salt Lakes region in Utah (Phllips et al. 1964, Andrews and Righter 1992, Pierotti and Good 1994, BISON-M, UDWR). 

Habitat for this species is similar during migration and on its wintering range. The Herring Gull utilizes the open waters of lakes, rivers, and reservoirs, intertidal areas on sandy beaches and mudflats, refuse dumps, and ploughed fields (Andrews and Righter 1992, Pierotti and Good 1994, NatureServe 2004), and its distribution is associated with foraging habitats (Pierotti and Good 1994). Roosting sites are usually adjacent to foraging habitats in open areas such as fields, parking lots, and airport runways (Pierotti and Good 1994). 
 
N. Tarr, 21January2011.
